meta.title: Attitudes of Christians in Western Europe

data.text: The majority of Europe 's Christians are non-practicing , but they differ from religiously unaffiliated people in their views on God , attitudes toward Muslims and immigrants , and opinions about religion 's role in society .
In the United Kingdom , for example , there are roughly three times as many non-practicing Christians as there are church-attending Christians defined this way .

triplets.subject: church-attending Christians
triplets.full: church-attending Christians defined way

data.text: Even after a recent surge in immigration from the Middle East and North Africa , there are many more non-practicing Christians in Western Europe than people of all other religions combined .
These figures raise some obvious questions : What is the meaning of Christian identity in Western Europe today ?
And how different are non-practicing Christians from religiously unaffiliated Europeans - many of whom also come from Christian backgrounds ?

triplets.subject: many
triplets.full: many also come from Christian backgrounds

data.text: The Pew Research Center study - which involved more than 24,000 telephone interviews with randomly selected adults , including nearly 12,000 non-practicing Christians - finds that Christian identity remains a meaningful marker in Western Europe , even among those who seldom go to church .

triplets.subject: Christian identity
triplets.full: Christian identity remains meaningful marker in Western Europe

data.text: On the contrary , the religious , political and cultural views of non-practicing Christians often differ from those of church-attending Christians and religiously unaffiliated adults .

triplets.subject: religious views
triplets.full: religious views differ from those of church-attending Christians

data.text: Christian identity in Western Europe is associated with higher levels of negative sentiment toward immigrants and religious minorities .

triplets.subject: Christian identity
triplets.object: higher levels of negative sentiment toward immigrants
triplets.full: Christian identity is associated with higher levels of negative sentiment toward immigrants

data.text: Non-practicing Christians are less likely than church-attending Christians to express nationalist views .

triplets.subject: Non-practicing Christians
triplets.full: Non-practicing Christians express nationalist views

data.text: Church-attending Christians are more conservative on these issues , though even among churchgoing Christians , there is substantial support - and in several countries , majority support - for legal abortion and same-sex marriage .
Nearly all churchgoing Christians who are parents or guardians of minor children say they are raising those children in the Christian faith .

Even after statistical techniques are used to control for differences in education , age , gender and political ideology , the survey shows that churchgoing Christians , non-practicing Christians and unaffiliated Europeans express different religious , cultural and social attitudes .

triplets.subject: churchgoing Christians
triplets.full: churchgoing Christians express different religious attitudes

triplets.subject: unaffiliated Europeans
triplets.full: unaffiliated Europeans express different religious attitudes

triplets.subject: non-practicing Christians
triplets.full: non-practicing Christians express different religious attitudes

data.text: Most non-practicing Christians in Europe believe in God .

triplets.subject: Most non-practicing Christians
triplets.full: Most non-practicing Christians believe in God

data.text: While most church-attending Christians say they believe in God As described in the Bible , non-practicing Christians are more apt to say that they do not believe in the biblical depiction of God , but that they believe in some other higher power or spiritual force in the universe .
Non-practicing Christians and Nones also diverge sharply on this question ; most unaffiliated people in Western Europe do not believe in God or a higher power or spiritual force of any kind .
Majorities of non-practicing Christians and church-attending Christians believe in these ideas .
Majorities agree with the statements , There are no spiritual forces in the universe , only the laws of nature and Science makes religion unnecessary in my life .

These positions are held by smaller shares of church-attending Christians and non-practicing Christians , though in most countries roughly a quarter or more of non-practicing Christians say science makes religion unnecessary to them .

triplets.subject: positions
triplets.object: in countries roughly quarter more of non-practicing Christians say
triplets.full: positions are held in countries roughly quarter more of non-practicing Christians say

triplets.subject: positions
triplets.full: positions are held by smaller shares of church-attending Christians

data.text: In every country surveyed , church-attending Christians are much more likely than non-practicing Christians to favor government support for religious values .

triplets.subject: church-attending Christians
triplets.full: church-attending Christians favor government support for religious values

data.text: In Austria , for example , a majority of churchgoing Christians take this position , compared with 38 % of non-practicing Christians .

triplets.subject: majority
triplets.full: majority take position In Austria

triplets.subject: majority
triplets.full: majority take position compared with 38 % of non-practicing Christians

data.text: A clear pattern emerges : Both church-attending and non-practicing Christians are more likely than religiously unaffiliated adults in Western Europe to voice anti-immigrant and anti-minority views .
In the UK , 45 % of church-attending Christians say Islam is fundamentally incompatible with British values and culture , as do roughly the same share of non-practicing Christians .
35 % of churchgoing Christians and 36 % of non-practicing Christians in France say immigration to their country should be reduced , compared with 21 % of Nones who take this position .
In Finland , for example , just one-in-five churchgoing Christians favor reducing immigration , compared with larger shares among religiously unaffiliated adults and non-practicing Christians .

triplets.subject: one-in-five churchgoing Christians
triplets.object: larger shares among religiously unaffiliated adults
triplets.full: one-in-five churchgoing Christians favor compared with larger shares among religiously unaffiliated adults

triplets.subject: one-in-five churchgoing Christians
triplets.full: one-in-five churchgoing Christians favor for example

triplets.subject: one-in-five churchgoing Christians
triplets.full: one-in-five churchgoing Christians favor In Finland

triplets.subject: one-in-five churchgoing Christians
triplets.full: one-in-five churchgoing Christians reducing immigration

data.text: This is not to say that most Christians hold these views : On the contrary , by most measures and in most countries surveyed , only minorities of Christians voice negative opinions about immigrants and religious minorities .
The survey - a kind of snapshot in time - can not prove that Christian identity is now growing in Western Europe after decades of secularization .

The survey can help answer the question : What is the nature of Christian identity in Western Europe today , particularly among the large population that identifies as Christian but does not regularly go to church ?

As explained in greater detail throughout this report , the findings suggest that the answer is partly a matter of religious beliefs , partly a matter of attitudes toward the role of religion in society , and partly a matter of views on national identity , immigrants and religious minorities .
Within countries , non-practicing Christians are less likely than churchgoing Christians to say that ancestry is key to national identity .

triplets.subject: non-practicing Christians
triplets.full: non-practicing Christians churchgoing Christians

data.text: In other words , Christians as a whole in Western Europe tend to express higher levels of nationalist sentiment .

triplets.subject: Christians
triplets.full: Christians tend In other words

triplets.subject: Christians
triplets.full: Christians express higher levels of nationalist sentiment

data.text: This overall pattern is not driven by nationalist feelings solely among highly religious Christians or solely among non-practicing Christians .
Rather , at all levels of religious observance , these views are more common among Christians than among religiously unaffiliated people in Europe .
Vast majorities of non-practicing Christians and religiously unaffiliated adults across Western Europe favor legal abortion and same-sex marriage .
In some countries , there is not much difference on these questions between the attitudes of Christians who rarely attend church and adults who do not affiliate with any religion .

In every country surveyed , on the other hand , church-attending Christians are considerably more conservative than both non-practicing Christians and religiously unaffiliated adults on questions about abortion and same-sex marriage .
Summing up : On what issues do non-practicing Christians resemble nones ' ?

triplets.subject: non-practicing Christians
triplets.full: non-practicing Christians do resemble nones

data.text: And on what measures are they similar to church-attending Christians ?

While the religious , political and cultural views of non-practicing Christians in Western Europe are frequently distinct from those of church-attending Christians and religiously unaffiliated adults , on some issues non-practicing Christians resemble churchgoing Christians , and on others they largely align with Nones .

triplets.subject: Christians
triplets.object: frequently distinct from those of church-attending Christians
triplets.full: Christians resemble frequently distinct from those of church-attending Christians

triplets.subject: non-practicing Christians
triplets.full: non-practicing Christians churchgoing Christians

data.text: Religious beliefs and attitudes toward religious institutions are two areas of broad similarity between non-practicing Christians and church-attending Christians .
Most people in Western Europe describe themselves as Christians .
Across the region , fewer people say they are Christian now than say they were raised as Christians .

Several countries in Western Europe have been collecting census data on religion for decades , and these data indicate that the percentage of the population that identifies as Christian has fallen substantially since the 1960s , while the share of the population that does not identify with any religion has risen .

While Christians are by far the largest religious group in Western Europe , a substantial minority of the population in every country is religiously unaffiliated - also sometimes called Nones , a category that includes people who identify as atheist , agnostic or Nothing in particular .
The unaffiliated portion of the adult population ranges from as high as 48 % in the Netherlands to 15 % in Ireland , Italy and Portugal .

Among Christians , the gap is even bigger - two-thirds of U.S. Christians say religion is very important to them , compared with a median of 14 % of Christians in the 15 countries surveyed across Western Europe .
